author: pietjepuk
content:
A 1559-style tx will have a `maxFeePerGas` and `maxPriorityFeePerGas` field. There's no "max base fee per gas" field. 

If you want to have an 1559-style tx with the behavior of current txs (/first price auctions), you can set the `maxPriorityFeePerGas` equal to the `maxFeePerGas`. E.g. if the base fee is 200 Gwei, and you set both those fields to 500 Gwei, you _will_ pay 500 Gwei per gas (200 of which is burned, 300 goes to miner). If the base fee increases to e.g. , you will still pay 500 Gwei per gas (210 of which will be burned, and 290 of which will go to the miner).

Users like me (that don't care about position as much) will just use a `maxPriorityFeePerGas` of ~2 Gwei, and set the `maxFeePerGas` to something like 1.5 the current base fee. If the next block happens to be full, I'll get included the one after (or if that one's also full, the one after).

author: pietjepuk
content:
I don't know what wallets will implement, but there's a few calls scheduled with them on this very topic that you should then definitely listen in on if you're interested. My guess is something like "estimated cost is x USD, OK?" on the basic view. In the advanced view you could imagine:
- a slider for "inclusion in the next N blocks" that adjusts the `maxFeePerGas`.
- an "I want in the next block!" checkbox, and then you have to manually set a fee that goes to the miner (=`maxPriorityFeePerGas`, and `maxFeePerGas` then being the sum of the current base fee and `maxPriorityFeePerGas`).

author: pietjepuk
content:
On the first item I would say it's the other way around: we're going to have a much easier time to estimate what gas price is necessary to get a tx included. And no overpaying compared to others, as you get refunded the unspent amount up to `maxFeePerGas` (but also no low-balling of gas price anymore either obviously). And no/less possibility of side-channel payments; taking up block space on the Ethereum chain requires spending ETH (and not something else).

These and other things are mentioned and described in much more detail in the many resources already out there: https://hackmd.io/@timbeiko/1559-resources
